name: 1,3-propanedithiol
Reason: 1,3-propanedithiol has a melting point of -109.4 degrees Celsius. The basic unit, propane, has a melting point of -18.0 degrees Celsius. The introduction of two sulfur atoms linked in a ring, forming a disulfide bond, significantly increases the melting point due to the increased molecular weight and rigidity of the structure. Each sulfur atom can raise the melting point by approximately +10 degrees Celsius, giving a total increase of (10 degrees Celsius x 2 sulfur atoms) = 20 degrees Celsius. Additionally, the sulfur atoms form a rigid structure, which can participate in hydrogen bonding, further contributing to the melting point.
